Permits to kill these bears can cost many thousands of dollars.

For students, the words “the eyes of Texas are upon you” have been sung before and after every sporting event and commencement. Beyond the campus, the song is ever-present at weddings and funerals — and even space, where it was a wake-up call for astronauts on the Gemini, Apollo and Skylab missions.

content: With the New York charity circuit still on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Five Collectives Compete for the Turner Prize
description: The jurors were drawn to politically and socially engaged art, which was often about representing minority groups, the chair of the judges said.
content: LONDON — A group that runs raves for gay, transgender and queer people of color, and an association of artists with neurological conditions, are among five art collectives shortlisted for this year’s Turner Prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: San Francisco Makes Home of Lesbian Couple a Landmark
description: The home of Phyllis Lyon and Del Martin, the first same-sex couple to legally marry in California, was an integral meeting spot for activists.
content: The home of the first same-sex couple to legally marry in California will become a historical landmark, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors ruled this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Want to Party? You Might Need a ‘Vaccine Passport.’
description: At some parties and night clubs, C.D.C. vaccination cards are the new velvet rope.
content: You could hear the music from the sidewalk, high-spirited renditions of “Ice Ice Baby” and “MMMBop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jorge Ramos
title: A Mother’s Hug
description: We become immigrants because we have no other choice. My mom understood when I told her that I had to leave Mexico.
content: MEXICO CITY — Because of the pandemic, I hadn’t been able to travel to Mexico since last March. My mother lives there. I hadn’t seen her for more than a year. The fear of unwittingly exposing her to the virus kept me away. I waited until both of us had received two shots of the Covid-19 vaccine. And I waited another two weeks for her to develop full immunity. And then I jumped on the first flight out of Miami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Has the Pandemic Changed Dating Forever?
description: Boundaries. Meaningful connections. “Covid baggage.” Here’s what dating will look like in a post-pandemic world.
content: Eons ago, romance often involved dinner and a movie, a few drinks in a crowded bar or a goodnight kiss — intimate experiences the pandemic abruptly replaced with social distancing, mask-wearing and the threat of catching a deadly disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Paulo Gustavo, Comedian Who Lampooned Brazilian Mothers, Dies at 42
description: Weeks before falling ill, he urged his countrymen to consider laughter “an act of resistance.” One of the country’s most beloved actors, he died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A Jaw-Dropping Philip Glass Opera Is Finally on Video
description: “Satyagraha,” one of the Metropolitan Opera’s greatest stagings of the 21st century, has been released on DVD and CD.
content: For decades, Philip Glass fans have internalized a lesson: If you want to see his operas, plan to buy tickets and attend in person. Don’t expect the stagings to show up on DVD in a year or two, as most prominent productions do these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Mother’s Day is coming up: Make blueberry muffins or eggs Benedict, cinnamon toast or a festive lunch of fettuccine and asparagus.
content: Good morning. It’s Mother’s Day weekend, and, if you’re not quite ready yet to take up a big table in the back of the Cheesecake Factory for cinnamon-swirl pancakes and a glass of Champagne, you might consider hooking up the maternal figure in your life with something special and homemade this year, her second Mother’s Day spent under pandemic rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Krugman Wonks Out: Braking Bad? When the Fed Fights Inflation.
description: If you don’t think Janet Yellen was right, ask yourself why.
content: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By H.W. Brands
title: Annette Gordon-Reed’s Surprising Recollections of Texas
description: With “On Juneteenth,” Gordon-Reed recalls integrating her town’s school, and explains why she thinks back fondly on her native state.
content: ON JUNETEENTHBy Annette Gordon-Reed
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: The U.S.and Europe debate how to get vaccines to countries that need them most.
description: A global debate is heating up over how to get Covid-19 vaccines to the nations most in need.
content: A global debate is heating up over how to get Covid-19 vaccines to the nations most in need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Flaming Phone
description: What do you think this GIF is saying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: A Love of Sea Monsters Was the First Clue
description: In 2014, Caitlin Kiernan was not interested in dating. But when a close friend suggested that she go out with Kenny Kaplan, their mutual appreciation for a children’s TV show sealed the deal.
content: Two friends and a sea monster brought Caitlin Kiernan and Kenny Kaplan together. These were not your average friends, nor sea monster. The creature came courtesy of a 1970s children’s TV show about two boys and their briny buddy. The friends were a little more current.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden and Republicans Spar Over Unemployment as Job Gains Disappoint
description: The president said he saw no measurable evidence that a $300 federal boost in unemployment benefits was hurting the labor market, amid criticism from conservatives and business groups.
content: WASHINGTON — The disappointing jobs report released Friday by the Labor Department is posing the greatest test yet of President Biden’s strategy to revive the economy, with business groups and Republicans warning that the president’s policies are causing a labor shortage and that his broader agenda risks stoking runaway inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Geoff Crowther, 77, Dies; Guided Travelers Looking to Get Lost
description: An early author for Lonely Planet, he tempted a generation of adventurers on journeys to exotic locales full of surprises.
content: Geoff Crowther, whose advice in artisanal Baedekers and later as a pioneering author for the Lonely Planet backpackers’ guidebooks lured intrepid travelers to offbeat destinations, died on April 13 in South East Queensland, Australia. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: W.H.O. approves China’s Sinopharm vaccine for emergency use.
description: Sinopharm is the first Chinese shot to be classified as safe and effective by the World Health Organization, allowing the vaccine to be more widely distributed to poor and middle-income nations.
content: The World Health Organization on Friday approved China’s Sinopharm’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, easing the way for poorer nations to get access to another much-needed shot to help end the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Pact to Go to the Prom Leads to a Walk Down the Aisle
description: Amy Larko and Blake Falanga knew they had each other if neither was dating anyone else when their senior dance arrived. They have been best friends since seventh grade.
content: Amy Katherine Larko and Blake Falanga, best friends since seventh grade, made a pact in 2011, the beginning of senior year at New Trier High School in Winnetka, Ill. If neither was seeing anyone seriously they would go to the senior prom together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Help Wanted: Someone With Money and Connections
description: SPACs have taken off during the pandemic, and they’re looking for directors who can help find a company to merge with.
content: So you’ve been asked to become a director of a special purpose acquisition company, more commonly known as a SPAC. The job has something in common with being a director of a company. But there’s one big difference: Instead of overseeing a company that is building, selling or creating something, you’re in charge of a big pot of money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Can Companies Require Vaccination, and Should They?
description: Employers are debating the pros and cons of mandating workers to get vaccinated.
content: As companies make plans to fully reopen their offices across the U.S., some in a matter of weeks, they face a delicate decision. Many would like all employees to be vaccinated when they return, but in the face of legal and P.R. risks, few employers have gone so far as to require it, Gillian Friedman and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch report for The Times. Instead, they are hoping that encouragement and incentives will suffice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A Dinner Anchored by Salmon, and Worth Celebrating
description: For a light, celebratory meal, David Tanis looks to wild fish, arugula, spring vegetables, and, for dessert, pistachios and strawberries.
content: Now that pandemic restrictions are easing, it’s a sheer joy to gather friends around the table again. After many, many months of distancing, a small dinner party feels every bit like a holiday, a very welcome one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: G.O.P. Focuses on Polarizing Cultural Issues in Drive to Regain Power
description: As Democrats prepare to run on an ambitious economic agenda, Republicans are working to caricature them as liberal extremists out of touch with voters’ values.
content: WASHINGTON — Minutes after a group of congressional Democrats unveiled a bill recently to add seats to the Supreme Court, the Iowa Republican Party slammed Representative Cindy Axne, a Democrat and potential Senate candidate, over the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Inside Democrats’ Scramble to Repel the G.O.P. Voting Push
description: Lacking effective legislative or legal ways to stop Republicans from introducing new voting limits, Democrats are applying pressure on their allies in Washington and trying to energize supporters.
content: Democrats are struggling to build a surefire legal strategy to block new Republican-backed restrictions on voting rights, relying on broadly worded warnings and urgent pleas that are designed, in part, to build political pressure on the White House, Congress and the Justice Department to act, as well as to engage their supporters to mobilize in advance of the 2022 midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Musicians Say Streaming Doesn’t Pay. Can the Industry Change?
description: Services like Spotify and Apple Music pulled the business back from the brink. But artists say they can’t make a living. And their complaints are getting louder.
content: When the pandemic hit last year, the British singer-songwriter Nadine Shah saw her income dry up in an instant. The concert bookings that sustained her vanished and, at age 34, she moved back in with her parents on the northeast coast of England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are you looking for work or workers? We’d like to hear from you.
description: Everyone’s story is personal. What is yours?
content: The nation’s economic upheaval is subsiding now that Covid-19 vaccinations are spreading and restrictions are lifting. But the transition is rocky and filled with uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Here We Go Again: Another Covid Case Brings More Uncertainty
description: These outbreaks should be getting less significant as more Australians get vaccinated. But that has been a slow, ungainly process.
content: I’ve spent the past 24 hours jumping at phone alerts and periodically Googling “NSW covid” and “Victoria border restrictions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The weak jobs report could help the Fed justify its patient approach to its policies.
description: Officials have said that they want to see real, not just forecast, progress toward full employment and stable inflation.
content: Federal Reserve officials have been facing a chorus of criticism for pledging to keep interest rates at rock bottom and for buying government-backed bonds at an enormous scale even as the United States economy bounces back from the pandemic. But after a weaker-than-expected April jobs report, they may have an easier time selling the idea that patience is a virtue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: He Wasn’t a Bird Person. Then a Hawk Built a Nest on His Fire Escape.
description: Life, death, renewal and social media ensued.
content: Michael Palma Mir’s first encounter with the hawk was not auspicious. Around the first of March, he noticed it outside his West Harlem apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Beware of Car Towing Companies That Patrol Private Parking Lots
description: Your car may have been towed for legitimate reasons — you parked in a loading zone, for instance. But in some cases, you may have been the victim of a towing company looking to earn fees.
content: Maybe you’ve had that sinking feeling of returning to where you thought you had parked your car, only to find an empty spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: Washingtonian staff protests C.E.O.’s article on remote work by refusing to publish.
description: Cathy Merrill of Washington Media wrote in The Washington Post that people who wanted to keep working from home risked losing status as full-time workers.
content: Editorial staff members at Washingtonian are refusing to publish online on Friday after the D.C.-based magazine’s chief executive wrote an opinion piece about the future of remote work that generated an immediate backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
title: Russian Spy Team Left Traces That Bolstered C.I.A.’s Bounty Judgment
description: But the U.S. lacked “evidence that the Kremlin directed this operation,” newly declassified information about the Russian team showed.
content: WASHINGTON — In early 2020, members of a Taliban-linked criminal network in Afghanistan detained in raids told interrogators that they had heard that Russians were offering money to reward killings of American and coalition troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Beyond Abstract Expressionism: MoMA Rethinks the Art of the 1950s
description: A selection of 79 drawings from the collection recasts the most celebrated decade in American art as less American.
content: As exhibitions go, “Degree Zero: Drawing at Midcentury” at the Museum of Modern Art is a relatively modest undertaking. After all, it is simply a show of 79 drawings from the museum’s permanent collection, a kind of potpourri if you will. But it is also an ambitious effort — selected and installed with great care by Samantha Friedman, an associate curator of drawings and prints. You sense a fresh point of view almost as soon as you enter the gallery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Restaurants and Broadway Are Coming Back. What About Our Schools?
description: As the city reopens, parents, teachers and students remain stuck in a hybrid-learning holding pattern.
content: On the morning of May 1, about a hundred parents deeply aggrieved at how the academic year has panned out and concerned about the next, gathered in a playground in East Harlem to demand that the city’s public schools reopen fully and without delay. The agenda might have confounded anyone who has not paid close attention to all the preceding chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Is Seeing Virus Cases Go Down and Vaccinations Go Up
description: The country appears to be breaking a tough third wave of the virus, and one of its tools is the AstraZeneca vaccine, which it spent months questioning.
content: BERLIN — Dr. Peter Weitkamp placed an ad in eBay’s classifieds last week, offering appointments for an AstraZeneca vaccine — “free/to give away” — to anyone over 60. Many of his own patients didn’t want it, since the German government had spent months questioning the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: I Became a Mother at 25, and I’m Not Sorry I Didn’t Wait
description: More women are delaying parenthood because they think having kids early will be hard. It is. It's also great.
content: If someone had asked on the day of my college graduation whether I imagined I would still be, in five years’ time, a reliable wallflower at any given party, I would have guessed so. Some things just don’t change. What I would not have predicted at the time is that five years hence I would be lurking along the fringes of a 3-year-old’s birthday party, a bewildered and bleary-eyed 27-year-old mom among a cordial flock of Tory Burch bedecked mothers in their late 30s and early 40s who had a much better idea of what they were doing than I ever have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China’s Vaccine Diplomacy Just Got a Big Win. But Can the Country Deliver?
description: The World Health Organization has approved a Chinese vaccine for emergency use. The announcement comes at a time when officials in the country are warning of a domestic shortage.
content: Developing countries racing for coronavirus vaccines now have another dependable option, according to the World Health Organization. And China’s reputation as a rising scientific superpower just got a big boost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Mark Morris Live(ish) Seems Almost Like Old Times
description: The Mark Morris Dance Group livestreamed a performance that featured a new work of substance, set to Brahms waltzes.
content: Not quite back to how things used to be; not the return of everything, but the return of much, which sometimes feels like plenty. I could be describing my life these days, or maybe yours, but I’m talking about the Mark Morris Dance Group’s “Live From Brooklyn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: For Chakaia Booker, Whose Medium Is Tires, the Art Is in the Journey
description: First things first: “I sculpt myself every day,” says Booker, who appears swathed in yards of textiles, from headdress to sneakers.
content: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — Chakaia Booker’s studio here is 20,000 square feet of unheated space, with a roof that leaks and a squirrel problem. Its floor is grooved in places with tracks from its past life as a trolley maintenance shed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: How a Wine Spritz Entrepreneur Spends Her Sundays
description: Jordan Salcito takes time on the weekend to support small businesses, as well as parks and museums, around the city.
content: Jordan Salcito and her husband, Robert Bohr, live and work in a world of upscale wine and food. Ms. Salcito was a sommelier at Eleven Madison Park and David Chang’s Momofuku restaurants before starting Ramona, her own line of canned, Italian-style wine spritzes, in 2016. Mr. Bohr, who was also a noted sommelier and restaurant owner, is now running a wine importing business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A C.D.C. official who early on warned that the coronavirus would upend American lives resigns.
description: Dr. Nancy Messonnier’s departure may signal more changes at the C.D.C. division she led.
content: Dr. Nancy Messonnier, who famously warned the nation early last year that the coronavirus would upend their lives, resigned from her position at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Michelangelo Lovelace, Artist of Street Life in Cleveland, Dies at 60
description: His vibrant paintings of the urban Black experience, and his sketches of nursing home residents he cared for as an aide, drew increasing notice in his last years.
content: Michelangelo Lovelace, an artist whose poignant sketches of people he cared for as a nursing home aide and whose bold paintings of urban Black life gained increasing attention and critical praise late in his life, died on April 26 at his home in Cleveland. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Virginia G.O.P.’s choices for governor: ‘Trumpy, Trumpier, Trumpiest.’
description: MIDLOTHIAN, Va. — One candidate brands himself a “conservative outlaw.” Another boasts of her bipartisan censure by the State Senate for calling the Capitol rioters “patriots.” A third, asked about Dominion voting machines — the subject of egregious conspiracy theories on the right — called them “the most important issue” of the campaign.
content: MIDLOTHIAN, Va. — One candidate brands himself a “conservative outlaw.” Another boasts of her bipartisan censure by the State Senate for calling the Capitol rioters “patriots.” A third, asked about Dominion voting machines — the subject of egregious conspiracy theories on the right — called them “the most important issue” of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Best Foot Forward
description: With more people getting vaccinated and back into the swing of things, a little advice from a self-proclaimed “outfit architect”: Buy yourself a pair of nice sneakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
title: Taiwan Court Upholds Laws Restricting Hunting
description: The decision was criticized by Indigenous rights activists who say traditional taboos and customs around hunting make such laws unnecessary.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwan’s Constitutional Court on Friday upheld several key provisions of two laws that restrict hunting, in a setback to the island’s Indigenous rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Gee
title: Art’s Greatest Enemy Might Not Be Science
description: In two new books, “Wonderworks” and “The Modern Myths,” writers at the intersection of aesthetics and empiricism reveal the humanities at war within themselves.
content: WONDERWORKS The Twenty-Five Most Powerful Inventions in the History of LiteratureBy Angus Fletcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: The One Book Stacey Abrams Would Require the President to Read
description: The Georgia politician and romance writer, whose latest novel is the thriller “While Justice Sleeps,” recommends “Master of the Senate,” by Robert Caro: “It is a seminal work on the nature of power, the limits of the presidency and the awesome demands politics make on the soul.”
content: Stacey Abrams, the Georgia politician and romance writer, whose latest novel is the thriller “While Justice Sleeps,” recommends “Master of the Senate,” by Robert Caro: “It is a seminal work on the nature of power, the limits of the presidency and the awesome demands politics make on the soul.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Angier
title: Meet the Other Social Influencers of the Animal Kingdom
description: Culture, once considered exclusive to humans, turns out to be widespread in nature.
content: Julia, her friends and family agreed, had style. When, out of the blue, the 18-year-old chimpanzee began inserting long, stiff blades of grass into one or both ears and then went about her day with her new statement accessories clearly visible to the world, the other chimpanzees at the Chimfunshi wildlife sanctuary in Zambia were dazzled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Fed and the S.E.C. chair have their eyes on meme stocks and the Archegos fallout.
description: The Federal Reserve’s Financial Stability Report, released Thursday, followed an unusual six months for markets. Over that period, stocks climbed steadily as the U.S. economic outlook rebounded, and stories of excess began to crop up, such as the frothy markets around so-called “meme stocks” such as GameStop and huge losses at a number of banks tied to problems at a hedge fund, Archegos Capital Management.
content: The Federal Reserve’s Financial Stability Report, released Thursday, followed an unusual six months for markets. Over that period, stocks climbed steadily as the U.S. economic outlook rebounded, and stories of excess began to crop up, such as the frothy markets around so-called “meme stocks” such as GameStop and huge losses at a number of banks tied to problems at a hedge fund, Archegos Capital Management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Job Growth Slowed in April, Muddling Expectations
description: The increase of 266,000 fell far short of estimates, though strong economic growth is still forecast for the months ahead.
content: The American jobs machine tottered last month, confounding optimistic forecasts of the labor market’s recovery and sharpening debates over the impact of federal pandemic-related jobless benefits on the nation’s work force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Ohio G.O.P. censures Representative Anthony Gonzalez for not supporting Trump.
description: They are also calling for Mr. Gonzalez to resign for being one of 10 Republican House members who voted to impeach Donald J. Trump after the Jan. 6 riot.
content: The Ohio Republican Party censured Representative Anthony Gonzalez on Friday and called for his resignation for voting to impeach former President Donald J. Trump in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Diaz
title: Pandemic Pantries in the Streets? You Communist!
description: People in the Philippines are stepping up to help one another where the state has failed them — only to be treated like insurgents.
content: MANILA — The day the city went back into a hard lockdown in late March, I started a ritual: Trapped again, I took to counting the ambulance sirens I’d hear from my place in Quezon City, the most populous area of this sprawling capital. At one point, blare after dystopian blare came every 20 minutes or so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: ‘It’s Not Quite Like Riding a Bike’: Pilots Get Ready to Fly Again
description: As airlines ramp up service, pilots who have been furloughed or laid off need to be retrained in everything from dealing with the control tower to “volcanic ash” scenarios.
content: One returning pilot lost control of an aircraft during landing and skidded off the runway into a ditch. Another just returning from furlough forgot to activate a critical anti-icing system designed to prevent hazards in cold weather. Several others flew at the wrong altitudes, which they attributed to distractions and lapses in communication.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Flourish, The Rock for President? and a 7-Eleven Grudge Match: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Ewan McGregor: Dahling, He’s Halston!
description: For a new Netflix series, the actor dropped his lightsaber and picked up the cigarettes and scissors.
content: When Ewan McGregor was but a wee lad in a sleepy town in Scotland in the ’70s, some 3,200 miles away in a Manhattan townhouse on East 63rd Street, Roy Halston Frowick was living on a diet of baked potatoes with beluga caviar, chilled Stolichnaya, rent boys and mounds of cocaine piled in Elsa Peretti silver ashtrays. (With silver straws to match.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Pfizer and BioNTech apply for full U.S. approval for their Covid vaccine.
description: The vaccine has been used under an emergency authorization since December. A decision by the Food and Drug Administration could take months.
content: Pfizer and the German company BioNTech have become the first companies to apply to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for full approval of their Covid-19 vaccine for use in people 16 and older. The vaccine is currently being administered to adults in America under an emergency use authorization granted in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: For Mother’s Day, a Healing Meditation on Mortality
description: An emotional episode of “The Midnight Gospel” on Netflix helped our critic process her own fears about loneliness and loss.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A 2-Minute Gap and Then a Return ‘I Love You’
description: Alexandra Ossa and Alexander Wong met at a themed “nerd party” at Duke. They both went dressed as Harry Potter.
content: Alexandra Ossa and Alexander Wong went on their first trip as a couple in January 2017 on a drive to the mountains of Asheville, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: For Super League , a Humbling Admission and a New War
description: Nine of a breakaway soccer league have admitted it was a mistake and agreed to pay millions in fines. But three holdouts are vowing to seek damages.
content: Less than two weeks after they became partners in a European Super League that would have cast aside the structures and organizations that have underpinned soccer on the Continent for nearly a century, a group of the sport’s biggest clubs are now engaged in a new battle behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sirin Kale
title: For Lolly Adefope, Comedy Is in the Details
description: The British actress has a sharp eye for the nuances of human behavior, as we see in the new season of Hulu’s “Shrill.”
content: LONDON — Lolly Adefope has range. In the last few years, the 30-year-old actress and comedian has appeared on TV as the sweet-natured specter of an 18th-century noblewoman (in the BBC comedy “Ghosts”), an exuberant hairdresser sleeping her way through Portland’s queer scene (in the Hulu dramedy “Shrill”) and God’s apathetic assistant (in TBS’s “Miracle Workers”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: A New Demographic Surprise for California: Population Loss
description: State data released on Friday showed that California’s population decreased in 2020, reflecting a decades-long pattern of slow growth.
content: SACRAMENTO — For the first time in more than a century, California recorded a net loss in population last year, a demographic reversal caused by the deadly toll of the coronavirus and declining immigration and birthrates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: When Love and Politics Mix
description: Emorie Broemel and Philip Swartzfager II met in Cleveland at the 2016 Republican National Convention. She was there working for ViacomCBS; he was a volunteer.
content: Emorie Broemel, a senior director of government relations at ViacomCBS, never imagined she would meet her future husband at the 2016 Republican National Convention in Cleveland. As a Democrat, it was one of the last places she expected to find love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Will U.S. employers mandate vaccinations for workers?
content: As employers in the U.S. bring workers back to the office, they’ll face a fraught question: Should they require employees to be vaccinated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Giovanni Russonello
title: An Anthem About Hugging Your Friends Again, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Rostam, Marcellus Juvann, Gogo Penguin and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk: Memelord or Meme Lifter?

content: Ever since a computer file made by the digital artist known as Beeple sold at auction in March for $69 million, observers of the art world have been fascinated and bewildered by the astronomical spike in prices for this type of work — so-called NFT-based art. These are digital creations that, because they are otherwise easily susceptible to being copied and reproduced, are sold as unique assets in the form of nonfungible tokens, or NFTs, which use blockchain technology to certify authenticity and proof of ownership. (Beeple’s piece was a collage of images that he had posted online every day since 2007.)

content: GLASGOW — For Scots of my generation — millennial and younger — the belief that Scotland would be better off running its own affairs, free from the strictures of Westminster, is almost axiomatic. From the Iraq war to Brexit, the financial crash to austerity, Britain feels trapped in a spiral of crisis and decline. According to a September analysis of recent polls, more than 70 percent of Scots under the age of 35 think Scotland should abandon the United Kingdom. And the abrasive right-wing premiership of Boris Johnson, increasingly mired in accusations of cronyism and sleaze, has only strengthened that view.
